segments.text: Everything changed in an instant, and her absence was so palpable.
Wherever you turned your head, wherever thoughts or glances wandered for a moment, you knew with deep understanding that she was gone.
They sat Shiva, shared memories, and spoke well of her with everyone who came.
Those days were long and quieter than usual.
It seemed like everyone spoke in whispers and tiptoed carefully.
In her mind, she understood Lucy was dead, but her heart refused to comprehend, and she only wanted to play, to scream out her torn soul on these black and white keys, her lifelong companions.
those keys, knowing her soul and every passing breeze through it.
The one that gently and quietly guides her fingers, the cheerful one that adds something stormy and upbeat to the melody.
And the one where small angers have accumulated, striking the keys with force, with pain, without mercy.
They didn't follow the book.
They didn't know the rules.
And Yosef had no idea when it began and when it ended.
There were no prayers at the day's end.
They simply stayed in their pink house, hosting warmly anyone who arrived, listening to the kind words everyone had about Lucy.
But she just wanted to play, feeling that any moment she might lose control, lift the piano lid and pour her sorrow into it.
It was so tangible that at a certain moment, she simply turned her back, lest she give in to that feeling.
There's a limit.
You don't play during Shiva.
During all those days, she felt cold.
It was winter, yet this wasn't about the weather.
It was a bone-chilling cold.
Danny, who called her Annabelle Lee, told her it was the cold in her heart and draped a soft warm coat his father had sent from New York over her shoulders.
Take it, he said, to warm you.
He recognized her heart torn with grief amidst the bravery she tried to show.
Come on, let's go for a walk.
Let's pick oranges," he offered, taking her to the grove near the French holiday village, walking several kilometers in the wonderful winter air, healing the soul, giving her space to breathe.
He talked to her all the way about the upcoming flight course, about his father who stayed in New York and her own beautiful mother who was no more.
He talked, and she listened to his rambling, which had something soothing about it.
He liked telling her things.
He always said so.
They returned loaded with oranges in his shirt, which he had taken off along the way.
And as soon as they entered the house, she realized nothing had helped.
She just wanted to play.
The house was empty.
Only Yosef came to greet them.
And before she knew it, her feet carried her to the piano.
She gently lifted the lid and sat on the bench in front of it, hearing a melody playing softly, sadly from afar, ready to swear she heard Lucy asking her to play her song.
Yves Montan's autumn leaves.
Her fingers moved on the keys, but the melody seemed to play itself.
Beside her stood Yosef and Danny, still holding his shirt full of oranges, both of them gazing at her tenderly in wonder, understanding she just wanted to play.
she had to play.
This was her way of silently screaming her soul.
The soul has its own rules, even in matters of mourning.
